title: Paul Gladwell dies at Pakefield Pontins after 'being restrained by staff' | Metro News
text:
Richard Hartley-Parkinson for Metro.co.uk Thursday 16 Feb 2017 2:41 pm Paul Gladwell has died after being restrained by holiday camp staff (Picture: Facebook) 
A man has died after he was allegedly restrained by staff at a Pontins holiday camp. 
Paul Gladwell, 38, is believed to have got into an argument with another man after claiming that his two-year-old son was being bullied. 
They then got involved in an altercation at the camp near Lowestoft, Suffolk. 10kg block of ice 'falls from plane' and smashes through man's garage roof 
Witnesses said that three security staff held on to Mr Gladwell’s arms and legs while another kneeled on him in a bar on Tuesday evening. 
He was arrested on suspicion of assault but while being driven to a police station he fell unwell and an ambulance was called to take him to hospital where he arrived in a critical condition. 
Mr Gladwell is said to have been on holiday with his partner Carrie Bennett and their three young sons. Paul Gladwell is believed to have got into an argument with another man leading to him being restrained by staff (Picture: Google Street View) 
Carrie’s sister Tiazah Rogers, 20, said on Facebook that Mr Gladwell had been left brain dead after being starved of oxygen. 
She said: ‘When they realised something was wrong they took him to hospital where he had to be resuscitated and died 4 times before being put into an induced coma due to his brain being very swollen and bleeding.’ 
The case has been referred by Suffolk Police to the Independent Police Complaints Commission. 
Pontins have not yet responded to requests for comment. 
A Suffolk Police statement said: ‘Police were called around 11.45pm on Tuesday night, 14 February, to reports of an altercation at premises at London Road, Pakefield, Lowestoft. 
‘Officers attended and found a man in his late 30s had been detained by staff on the site. The man was arrested on suspicion of assault. Trump reassures everyone by saying he wants to avoid a 'nuclear holocaust' 
‘As he was being transported to Great Yarmouth Police Investigation Centre in a marked police van he became unwell. The man was then taken to the James Paget hospital. 
‘As is standard procedure in cases of this nature, the incident has been referred to the IPCC. A full investigation into what happened is underway’ 
An IPCC spokesman said: ‘The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) has launched an independent investigation after a man died following an arrest carried out by officers with Suffolk Constabulary. 
‘Paul Gladwell, 38, from Colchester was initially detained by staff at Pontins Holiday Park, London Road, Kessingland, Lowestoft at about 11.40pm, 14 February and subsequently arrested on suspicion of assault. 
‘While being transported to Great Yarmouth Police Investigation Centre in a police van officers became concerned for his wellbeing, stopped the van, and contacted an ambulance. 
‘The man was treated at the scene before being taken to hospital by ambulance in a critical condition. Sadly earlier today, 16 February, Mr Gladwell was pronounced dead. 
‘The incident was referred to the IPCC, an independent investigation has been launched, and a team has attended the scene and post incident procedure. His family has been informed. 
‘Investigators are carrying out house-to-house enquiries, speaking to witnesses and gathering CCTV footage.’ 
IPCC Commissioner Cindy Butts said: ‘Our thoughts are with the man’s relatives and friends at this difficult time. Our investigators will be conducting a thorough enquiry into all the circumstances surrounding his interaction with the police.’ 
Anyone who witnessed the incident is asked to contact the IPCC by email at witness@ipcc.gsi.gov.uk or by telephone on 0800 096 9070. More
